You can call this method from synchronous code using a completion handler, as shown on this page, or you can call it as an asynchronous method that has the following declaration:

code: func providePlaceholder(at url: URL) async throws

inlineContent.text: For information about concurrency and asynchronous code in Swift, see
The system calls this method when it needs a placeholder for a document that’s returned by the File Provider extension, but is not stored locally. Override
to create a placeholder for the given URL. This task can be broken into three steps: looking up the document’s file provider item, writing the placeholder, and calling the completion handler.
Both the
and

methods can be triggered as other processes attempt to access documents provided by the File Provider extension. These methods may be called in response to user interaction with the document browser, or due to a coordinated read or coordinated write of the document’s URL.
Exactly which methods are triggered, and their sequence, depends on the type of coordinated access. For example, a coordinated read using the
option triggers only the creation of a placeholder. As a result, your extension should not create dependencies between these methods. They may be called in any order.

content.text: Look Up the Document’s File Provider Item

inlineContent.text: Get the document’s persistent identifier by calling
, and pass in the value of the
parameter.
Call
, and pass in the persistent identifier. This method returns the file provider item for the document.
Get the placeholder URL by calling
, and pass in the value of the url parameter.
Call
, and pass in the placeholder URL and the file provider item.

After writing the placeholder to disk, call the completion handler. If any errors occur, pass them to the completion handler. The system then passes the error back to the original coordinated read or write.

code: override func providePlaceholder(at url: URL, completionHandler: @escaping (Error?) -> Void) {
guard let identifier = persistentIdentifierForItem(at: url) else {

An extension other apps use to access files and folders managed by your app and synced with a remote storage.
The principal class for the nonreplicated File Provider extension.
Returns a description of the item associated with the persistent identifier.
Tells the File Provider extension that a document has changed.
Returns a unique identifier for the given URL.
Triggers the creation of a placeholder for the given URL.
Provides an actual file on disk for a placeholder.
Tells the File Provider extension that a given document is no longer being accessed.
Returns a placeholder URL for a given document URL.
Writes a document placeholder with the provided metadata.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
An object representing the location of a resource that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A value that identifies the location of a resource, such as an item on a remote server or the path to a local file.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
